title: Voters casts ballots in Vic in Catalan referendum
description:
(1 Oct 2017) Hundreds of Catalans began gathering outside polling stations in the early hours of Sunday as a disputed independence referendum takes place in Catalonia. 
In Vic, a town roughly one hour away from Barcelona, the heart of the independence voters beats as never before. 
Many people surrounded a school as Catalan police, known as "mossos" approached the organisers to take note of the situation only to leave shortly afterwards, leaving only a wave of applause behind as people chanted "I will vote."
Polls had been expected to open at 9 am local time (0700 GMT).
However, due to connection problems with the app especially created by the Catalan Government for the day, people were prevented from voting as soon as the doors were open. 
Almost two hours later people began casting their ballots. 
Electoral volunteers at various polling stations said they were unable to access census data because the website that hosted it was down, while the internet service had been cut in some of the stations.
Across the region, parents, children and activist volunteers had occupied some of the 2,315 schools and other facilities to avoid closure from police acting on court orders.
Spain's Constitutional Court ordered the vote to be suspended and central authorities said it was illegal. 
Regional separatist leaders are holding it anyway and promising to declare independence if the "yes" side wins.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/c54622d58eb6c7f89629e96b6ae465c5 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork
